sections.title: Introduction to Phage Display for Antibody Discovery
sections.tldr: Phage display is a powerful technology that enables the selection of antibodies with specific binding properties from large libraries displayed on bacteriophage surfaces. This technique leverages the connection between genotype and phenotype, allowing researchers to isolate antibodies with desired characteristics through iterative rounds of selection. (LLM Memory)
sections.text:
Phage display is a robust platform for antibody discovery that connects a protein's phenotype (binding properties) with its genotype (encoding DNA). The technology works by genetically fusing antibody fragments to bacteriophage coat proteins, causing the antibody to be "displayed" on the phage surface while its genetic information is safely packaged inside the phage particle. This physical linkage between an antibody and its gene enables researchers to isolate specific antibodies based on their binding properties and then recover their genetic information for further study and development. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

The most common phage display format uses filamentous phage (such as M13, fd, or f1), where antibody fragments—typically single-chain variable fragments (scFvs) or antigen-binding fragments (Fabs)—are fused to coat proteins like pIII or pVIII. The power of phage display lies in its ability to screen billions of different antibody variants simultaneously through a process called biopanning, where phage-displayed antibodies are exposed to an immobilized target antigen, unbound phage are washed away, and specifically bound phage are eluted and amplified for subsequent rounds of selection. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

The success of antibody discovery via phage display hinges critically on two main factors: the quality and diversity of the initial antibody library, and the effectiveness of the selection strategy. Libraries can be constructed from immunized or naïve sources, or through synthetic approaches that introduce designed diversity. After multiple rounds of selection, enriched antibodies can be characterized for binding affinity, specificity, stability, and other desirable properties, making phage display an invaluable tool for therapeutic antibody development. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

sections.title: Library Size and Diversity
sections.tldr: The size and diversity of a phage display library are critical factors that directly correlate with the probability of isolating high-affinity antibodies. Larger libraries (typically 10^9-10^11 members) with functional diversity across multiple frameworks and CDRs provide the best chance of discovering antibodies with desirable binding and biophysical properties. (15 sources)
sections.text:
Library size and diversity represent the cornerstone parameters that determine the success of antibody discovery using phage display technology. The quality of an antibody library is fundamentally dependent on its complexity or diversity, which directly reflects the probability of finding high-affinity antibodies against any given target <Paper corpusId="219399137" paperTitle="(Bashir et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="258334472" paperTitle="(Huang et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. Multiple studies have demonstrated a linear correlation between library size and the highest obtainable antibody affinity, indicating that larger libraries significantly enhance the chances of isolating high-quality binders <Paper corpusId="198254683" paperTitle="(Peltomaa et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="58554427" paperTitle="(Valadon et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

Modern phage display libraries typically aim for a diversity of 10^9 to 10^11 independent clones <Paper corpusId="14583194" paperTitle="(Kugler et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="22982240" paperTitle="(Leow et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. Due to technical limitations, particularly during bacterial transformation, achieving libraries larger than 10^11 variants remains challenging even with optimization <Paper corpusId="221342908" paperTitle="(Alfaleh et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. The phage display format enables high density of particles (10^13 particles/mL), allowing for effective representation of extensive antibody diversity in a single library <Paper corpusId="233424160" paperTitle="(Lin et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

While library size is crucial, functional diversity—the proportion of displayed antibodies that are correctly folded and capable of binding—is equally important. Issues such as stop codons, reading frame shifts, and poor expression can reduce functional diversity <Paper corpusId="221342908" paperTitle="(Alfaleh et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. An effective library should not only be large but also display antibody variants as functional fragments with proper folding and minimal biophysical liabilities <Paper corpusId="10576257" paperTitle="(Ponsel et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>.

The source of diversity significantly impacts library quality. Libraries can be categorized as:

1. Natural libraries (naïve or immunized) - derived from B cells of donors
2. Synthetic libraries - constructed using designed diversity in CDRs
3. Semi-synthetic libraries - combining natural and synthetic elements

 <Paper corpusId="258863772" paperTitle="(Zhang, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

The number of donors has traditionally been considered important for maximizing diversity, with some libraries using B cells from numerous individuals <Paper corpusId="14583194" paperTitle="(Kugler et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>. However, recent research suggests that the total number of lymphocytes, rather than the number of donors, may be the critical factor, with evidence that a single donor with sufficient lymphocytes can produce a highly functional library <Paper corpusId="232296539" paperTitle="(Erasmus et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="269574517" paperTitle="(Lee et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

The design of complementarity-determining regions (CDRs) is another crucial consideration. Libraries may diversify all six CDRs or focus primarily on the most variable regions (CDR-H3 and CDR-L3) <Paper corpusId="246433314" paperTitle="(Davydova, 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. The amino acid diversity and distribution in CDRs, particularly in CDR-H3, plays a vital role in library functionality <Paper corpusId="14583194" paperTitle="(Kugler et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>.

Framework selection also impacts library quality. While some successful libraries use a single framework pair, libraries incorporating multiple frameworks generally provide better structural diversity to accommodate various epitopes <Paper corpusId="258863772" paperTitle="(Zhang, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. Frameworks are typically selected based on their frequency in natural repertoires, stability, expression levels, and display efficiency.

The evolution of library design has shifted from focusing solely on size and affinity to also considering developability factors such as expression, stability, and production characteristics <Paper corpusId="10576257" paperTitle="(Ponsel et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>. This holistic approach aims to generate not just high-affinity binders but antibodies with favorable biophysical properties suitable for therapeutic development <Paper corpusId="221342908" paperTitle="(Alfaleh et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="58554427" paperTitle="(Valadon et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="54630768" paperTitle="(Perez et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

In summary, the construction of a high-quality phage display library with optimal size and diversity remains fundamental to successful antibody discovery <Paper corpusId="257725782" paperTitle="(Choi et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. The continuous evolution of library design approaches reflects the industry's growing understanding of the complex relationship between library characteristics and the ability to isolate antibodies with desired therapeutic properties.

snippets: More the three decades ago, the seminal works by George Smith (Smith, 1985)(Scott et al., 1990) and Greg Winter 6 gave birth to the phage display technology as a platform for peptide and antibody discovery. In the subsequent thirty plus years practicing phage display, it has been well established that the size and functionality of a library are critical parameters for success in isolating specific and high affinity antibodies from said library. Early selections from antibody phage-displayed libraries of 10 7 members generated ~90 nM antibody fragments to diverse proteins. (Marks et al., 1991) Further studies using larger libraries, e.g., >10 10 members, (Haard et al., 1999)(Vaughan et al., 1996) produced antibody fragments with single-digit nM or sub-nM affinities. Similarly, a synthetic library called the Griffiths' library 9 of >10 10 members produced sub-nM binders, whereas antibody fragments of >100 nM were obtained when a small portion of the library containing only 10 7 clones was used in the selection process.

snippets: In general, combinatorial antibody libraries are constructed from mRNA or 2 of 11 RNA extracted from B cells of immunized or naïve donors. Because the variable regions of the heavy chain (VH) and the light chain (VL) representing the immunoglobulin geneencoding repertoire are known, we can use polymerase chain reaction (PCR), and then specific primers to amplify different VH and VL gene families. These variable regions of antibody repertoires are then ligated to the phage display vector (phagemid), with the net result that the antibody is expressed on the surface of the phage and the gene encoding of the antibody is in the phage genome. The antibody-encoding gene is inserted into a phage coat protein gene causing the antibody fragment to be displayed on the outside of the phage, which results in a connection between genotype and phenotype. Once produced, the antibody library in the phage can be bound to an immobilized antigen. This allows us to use multiple binding and elution cycles for selection of antibodies with high affinity and specificity

Due to the small size and high solubility of phage particles (10 13 particles/mL), a library size of up to 10 11 independent clones can be effectively generated, and an extensive antibody diversity can be displayed in a single library. One advantage of combinatorial antibody library technology is the diversity of binders. Another advantage is the ability to directly generate human antibodies in vitro. Since many important therapeutic antibodies are antibodies to self-antigens, which is forbidden by tolerance, in vitro generation allows the by-passing of tolerance and the generation of antibodies to self-antigens such as cell surface proteins, or self-products such as Tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-α).

paper.title: Evolution of phage display libraries for therapeutic antibody discovery

snippets:
However, library design is highly variable and plays a central role in phage display-based antibody discovery.

According to the source of diversity, antibody phage libraries can be divided into natural, fully synthetic, and semisynthetic libraries ( Figure 1). In a natural library, diversity is derived entirely from natural repertoires, which can be either healthy, autoimmune, or immunized donors (named naïve, nonimmunized, and immunized libraries, respectively). In theory, a large naïve library can be used to isolate antibodies against any targets, but, if a library is constructed from immunized donors, diversity will be highly biased toward a specific target. For an immunized library constructed from human repertoires, it can be constructed from either vaccinated donors or donors who have recovered from infection or disease. In a fully synthetic library, the antibody frameworks are usually chosen from human antibody germlines that are well-represented and have shown superior developability. Complementarity-determining regions (CDRs) are designed based on antibody structure and application purpose. The quality of the synthetic DNA that are used to create CDR diversity plays a pivotal role in determining the functional size of a synthetic library.

Affinity is a key factor used to evaluate the quality of a phage library. It has been observed that affinity that can be achieved is correlated with the library size. We investigated the correlation between highest affinity values obtained from published universal phage libraries and library size (data not shown). In agreement with previous observations, there is a positive correlation between the two parameters. This is because a universal library is designed for antibody discovery against any given target. Therefore, a larger library (higher diversity) offers a greater chance of identifying high affinity antibodies.

Regarding framework usage in a phage display library, it is generally accepted that a library using multiple frameworks will perform better than one using a single pair of frameworks, since multiple scaffolds provide more structural diversity. For selection of framework, parameters, such as frequency in natural repertories, stability, expression, and display level, have been taken into consideration. Moreover, it should be noted that several heavy chain germline genes, e.g., certain IGVH4 family genes, have been found to be deselected during phage panning. Also, VH4-34 has been found to be associated with B cell cytotoxicity. Thus, these germlines should be excluded from the library design.

paper.title: A single donor is sufficient to produce a highly functional in vitro antibody library

snippets: Antibody complementarity determining region diversity has been considered to be the most important metric for the production of a functional antibody library. Generally, the greater the antibody library diversity, the greater the probability of selecting a diverse array of high affinity leads. According to this paradigm, the primary means of elevating library diversity has been by increasing the number of donors. In the present study we explored the possibility of creating an in vitro antibody library from a single healthy individual, showing that the number of lymphocytes, rather than the number of donors, is the key criterion in the production of a diverse and functional antibody library. We describe the construction of a high-quality phage display library comprising 5 × 10 9 human antibodies by applying an efficient B cell extraction protocol from a single donor and a targeted V-gene amplification strategy favoring specific antibody families for their improved developability profiles.

snippets: The antibody display system includes the phage display, yeast display, bacterial surface display, and ribosome display (Boder et al., 1997)(Gunneriusson et al., 1996)[30]. Among these systems, a phage display antibody library is a collection of diverse antibody fragments genetically fused to coat proteins on the surface of bacteriophages, allowing for the display of a wide range of antibodies [31][32](Azzazy et al., 2002)(McCafferty et al., 1990). It serves as a versatile and widely used tool for engineering antibodies and drug discovery (Kumar et al., 2019). The diversity of the library plays a pivotal role in isolating antibodies with high specificity for a given target using phage display technology

For naïve libraries constructed without any process of immunization, the theoretical diversity increases with the number of initially collected lymphocytes, enriching a more extensive range of potential binding specificities. Although it has been reported that a single donor is sufficient to produce a highly functional antibody library, recent studies of the B cell repertoire have suggested that individuals possess a unique immune system and do not extensively share common B cell clonotypes (Wang et al., 2016)(Erasmus et al., 2021). Hence, multiple donors' blood samples are beneficial for expanding the antibody library's repertoire. Therefore, we assumed that the construction of phage display libraries using numerous lymphocytes collected from an increased number of different donors would enhance the diversity of the library, leading to the rapid discovery of diverse high-quality antibodies.

paper.title: In vitro and in silico assessment of the developability of a designed monoclonal antibody library

snippets: ABSTRACT Despite major advances in antibody discovery technologies, the successful development of monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) into effective therapeutic and diagnostic agents can often be impeded by developability liabilities, such as poor expression, low solubility, high viscosity and aggregation. Therefore, strategies to predict at the early phases of antibody development the risk of late-stage failure of antibody candidates are highly valuable. In this work, we employ the in silico solubility predictor CamSol to design a library of 17 variants of a humanized mAb predicted to span a broad range of solubility values, and we examine their developability potential with a battery of commonly used in vitro and in silico assays. Our results demonstrate the ability of CamSol to rationally enhance mAb developability, and provide a quantitative comparison of in vitro developability measurements with each other and with more resource-intensive solubility measurements, as well as with in silico predictors that offer a potentially faster and cheaper alternative. We observed a strong correlation between predicted and experimentally determined solubility values, as well as with measurements obtained using a panel of in vitro developability assays that probe non-specific interactions. These results indicate that computational methods have the potential to reduce or eliminate the need of carrying out laborious in vitro quality controls for large numbers of lead candidates. Overall, our study provides support to the emerging view that the implementation of in silico tools in antibody discovery campaigns can ensure rapid and early selection of antibodies with optimal developability potential.

sections.title: Sources of Diversity in Phage Display Libraries
sections.tldr: Phage display libraries derive their diversity from three main sources: natural (naïve or immunized), synthetic, and semi-synthetic approaches. Each source offers distinct advantages in terms of antibody diversity, specificity, and developability properties that impact the success of antibody discovery campaigns. (8 sources)
sections.text:
Phage display libraries can be categorized based on their source of diversity:

1. **Natural Libraries**
 - **Naïve Libraries**: Constructed from B cells of non-immunized donors, providing broad unbiased diversity against any potential target <Paper corpusId="258863772" paperTitle="(Zhang, 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="252533961" paperTitle="(Andre et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>
 - **Immunized Libraries**: Derived from donors who have been vaccinated, infected, or recovered from disease, resulting in libraries biased toward specific targets with potentially high-affinity, naturally matured antibodies <Paper corpusId="23146468" paperTitle="(Nixon et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="258863772" paperTitle="(Zhang, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>
 - **Donor Considerations**: While traditionally multiple donors were used to maximize diversity, recent research suggests that the total number of lymphocytes, rather than donor count, may be the critical factor for library functionality <Paper corpusId="269574517" paperTitle="(Lee et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="232296539" paperTitle="(Erasmus et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

2. **Synthetic Libraries**
 - **Framework Selection**: Use carefully selected human antibody germline frameworks with favorable developability characteristics <Paper corpusId="258863772" paperTitle="(Zhang, 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="270629223" paperTitle="(Hutchings et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>
 - **CDR Design**: Employ rational design principles for CDR diversity, particularly focusing on CDR-H3 and CDR-L3 <Paper corpusId="270629223" paperTitle="(Hutchings et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>
 - **Minimalist Strategies**: Some libraries use binary code systems to diversify CDR-H3 while maintaining a single framework <Paper corpusId="270629223" paperTitle="(Hutchings et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>
 - **Framework Coverage**: Advanced synthetic libraries incorporate multiple frameworks (typically 7 VH and 7 VL families) that cover >95% of natural human antibody diversity <Paper corpusId="270629223" paperTitle="(Hutchings et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="15340484" paperTitle="(Knappik et al., 2000)" isShortName></Paper>

3. **Semi-Synthetic Libraries**
 - **Hybrid Approach**: Combine natural frameworks with synthetic CDR diversity <Paper corpusId="258863772" paperTitle="(Zhang, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>
 - **Optimized Design**: Focus on CDR diversity while maintaining frameworks with superior developability profiles <Paper corpusId="270629223" paperTitle="(Hutchings et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>
 - **Modular Construction**: Use restriction sites flanking CDRs to allow for easy swapping and optimization of diversity regions <Paper corpusId="15340484" paperTitle="(Knappik et al., 2000)" isShortName></Paper>

4. **Evolution of Library Design Philosophy**
 - **Early Focus**: Initial efforts concentrated primarily on maximizing library size and affinity <Paper corpusId="10576257" paperTitle="(Ponsel et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>
 - **Current Approach**: Modern libraries balance diversity with developability factors such as expression levels, stability, and production characteristics <Paper corpusId="10576257" paperTitle="(Ponsel et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="270629223" paperTitle="(Hutchings et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>
 - **Quality Considerations**: DNA quality in synthetic approaches significantly impacts the functional size of the library <Paper corpusId="258863772" paperTitle="(Zhang, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

snippets:
In the early days of antibody phage display, the initial focus was on generating large diverse repertoires (>10 10 transformants) to identify high affinity functional binders, which was subsequently followed by addressing aspects of sequence liabilities via synthetic approaches to resolve developability and expression challenges that occurred with some naturally occurring antibody sequences and errors introduced by initial synthetic approaches, as well as removal of T cell epitopes, for example, by the selection of frameworks that exhibited optimal stability and expression. These early synthetic libraries focused on using selected frameworks restricting diversity to the CDRs [49,50], but were unable to robustly generate high affinity antibodies against a broad range of protein targets. The design of complementarity-determining regions (CDRs) represents a fundamental aspect of phage display library construction that directly impacts antibody discovery outcomes. CDR design strategies have evolved significantly to balance functional diversity with developability considerations.

Most synthetic libraries focus diversification efforts on CDR-H3 and CDR-L3, as these regions contribute most significantly to antigen binding and specificity <Paper corpusId="14583194" paperTitle="(Kugler et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="246433314" paperTitle="(Davydova, 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="15340484" paperTitle="(Knappik et al., 2000)" isShortName></Paper>. However, some advanced libraries diversify all six CDRs to create more structurally diverse paratopes capable of recognizing a wider range of epitopes <Paper corpusId="246433314" paperTitle="(Davydova, 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="207047616" paperTitle="(Yang et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>.

CDR loop length variation has emerged as a critical design parameter, particularly for CDR-H3, which shows the greatest natural length variability. Studies have demonstrated that incorporating diverse loop lengths significantly enhances library functionality and target recognition capability <Paper corpusId="14583194" paperTitle="(Kugler et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="270629223" paperTitle="(Hutchings et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

Several approaches to amino acid distribution in CDRs have proven effective:

1. **Natural distribution mimicry**: Many libraries use trinucleotide synthesis technology to create CDR diversity that reflects amino acid distributions found in natural human antibodies <Paper corpusId="15340484" paperTitle="(Knappik et al., 2000)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="16251643" paperTitle="(Mandrup et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>.

2. **Minimalist approaches**: Surprisingly effective libraries have been constructed using binary code systems with just two amino acids (tyrosine and serine) in CDRs, highlighting the importance of aromatic residues in antibody-antigen interactions <Paper corpusId="246433314" paperTitle="(Davydova, 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="54479685" paperTitle="(Jian et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

3. **Structure-based design**: More sophisticated approaches incorporate knowledge of antibody-antigen complex structures to guide amino acid selection at specific positions <Paper corpusId="54479685" paperTitle="(Jian et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="273402071" paperTitle="(Almagro et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

4. **Developability-focused design**: Modern libraries avoid amino acids that could lead to post-translational modifications or other developability issues <Paper corpusId="20900714" paperTitle="(Tiller et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="273402071" paperTitle="(Almagro et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

The modular design of CDRs has become increasingly important, with many libraries incorporating unique restriction sites flanking CDR regions to facilitate subsequent affinity maturation through CDR shuffling or targeted mutagenesis <Paper corpusId="15340484" paperTitle="(Knappik et al., 2000)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="21530108" paperTitle="(Pini et al., 1998)" isShortName></Paper>. This modular approach allows for rapid optimization of selected antibodies without requiring knowledge of the particular sequence <Paper corpusId="15340484" paperTitle="(Knappik et al., 2000)" isShortName></Paper>.

Recent advancements include small perturbation mutagenesis strategies that use specific degenerate codons (such as NWG, NWC, and NSG) for amino acid saturation mutagenesis without introducing cysteine residues or stop codons <Paper corpusId="3155125" paperTitle="(Hu et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>. These approaches, combined with deep sequencing technologies, enable more sophisticated analysis of selection enrichment landscapes in CDR sequences and amino acid substitutions.

The evolution of CDR design philosophies reflects a shift from simply maximizing diversity to creating "smart diversity" that combines binding potential with favorable biophysical properties <Paper corpusId="258863772" paperTitle="(Zhang, 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="270629223" paperTitle="(Hutchings et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. This integrated approach aims to generate not just high-affinity binders but antibodies with superior developability characteristics suitable for therapeutic applications.

paper.title: Evolution of phage display libraries for therapeutic antibody discovery

snippets:
However, library design is highly variable and plays a central role in phage display-based antibody discovery.

According to the source of diversity, antibody phage libraries can be divided into natural, fully synthetic, and semisynthetic libraries ( Figure 1). In a natural library, diversity is derived entirely from natural repertoires, which can be either healthy, autoimmune, or immunized donors (named naïve, nonimmunized, and immunized libraries, respectively). In theory, a large naïve library can be used to isolate antibodies against any targets, but, if a library is constructed from immunized donors, diversity will be highly biased toward a specific target. For an immunized library constructed from human repertoires, it can be constructed from either vaccinated donors or donors who have recovered from infection or disease. In a fully synthetic library, the antibody frameworks are usually chosen from human antibody germlines that are well-represented and have shown superior developability. Complementarity-determining regions (CDRs) are designed based on antibody structure and application purpose. The quality of the synthetic DNA that are used to create CDR diversity plays a pivotal role in determining the functional size of a synthetic library.

Affinity is a key factor used to evaluate the quality of a phage library. It has been observed that affinity that can be achieved is correlated with the library size. We investigated the correlation between highest affinity values obtained from published universal phage libraries and library size (data not shown). In agreement with previous observations, there is a positive correlation between the two parameters. This is because a universal library is designed for antibody discovery against any given target. Therefore, a larger library (higher diversity) offers a greater chance of identifying high affinity antibodies.

Regarding framework usage in a phage display library, it is generally accepted that a library using multiple frameworks will perform better than one using a single pair of frameworks, since multiple scaffolds provide more structural diversity. For selection of framework, parameters, such as frequency in natural repertories, stability, expression, and display level, have been taken into consideration. Moreover, it should be noted that several heavy chain germline genes, e.g., certain IGVH4 family genes, have been found to be deselected during phage panning. Also, VH4-34 has been found to be associated with B cell cytotoxicity. Thus, these germlines should be excluded from the library design.

sections.text:
Framework selection represents a critical aspect of phage display library design that significantly impacts antibody discovery outcomes. Early phage display libraries often utilized single framework pairs, but modern approaches recognize that libraries incorporating multiple frameworks generally provide superior structural diversity to accommodate various epitope topologies <Paper corpusId="258863772" paperTitle="(Zhang, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. This evolution reflects a growing understanding that structural diversity from different frameworks complements sequence diversity within CDRs.

The most advanced synthetic libraries typically incorporate seven VH and seven VL (four Vκ and three Vλ) germline families that collectively cover more than 95% of natural human antibody diversity <Paper corpusId="258863772" paperTitle="(Zhang, 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="15340484" paperTitle="(Knappik et al., 2000)" isShortName></Paper>. These frameworks are carefully selected based on several key parameters, including their frequency in natural repertoires, structural stability, expression efficiency, and display levels on phage surfaces <Paper corpusId="258863772" paperTitle="(Zhang, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

Framework selection has evolved significantly from early approaches that focused primarily on maximizing diversity and affinity to more sophisticated strategies that balance these factors with developability considerations <Paper corpusId="10576257" paperTitle="(Ponsel et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>. Modern libraries prioritize frameworks with favorable biophysical properties that minimize aggregation, improve expression, and enhance manufacturing characteristics <Paper corpusId="270629223" paperTitle="(Hutchings et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

Importantly, frameworks known to be associated with developability issues are deliberately excluded from modern library designs. For example, certain IGHV4 family genes have been observed to be deselected during phage panning, and VH4-34 has been associated with B cell cytotoxicity, making these germlines poor candidates for inclusion in therapeutic antibody libraries <Paper corpusId="258863772" paperTitle="(Zhang, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

The modular design of frameworks has become increasingly important in library construction. By introducing unique restriction sites flanking CDR regions, modern libraries enable rapid optimization through CDR shuffling or targeted mutagenesis without requiring detailed knowledge of the particular sequence <Paper corpusId="270629223" paperTitle="(Hutchings et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="15340484" paperTitle="(Knappik et al., 2000)" isShortName></Paper>. This modular approach greatly facilitates subsequent affinity maturation campaigns.

Recent advanced library designs have taken framework optimization a step further by focusing on residues outside the traditional CDR regions that may still influence binding. For example, some libraries incorporate diversification in positions that bind both protein and peptide targets based on analysis of antibody-antigen complexes of known structure <Paper corpusId="273402071" paperTitle="(Almagro et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. These approaches use amino acid frequencies found in human antibody sequences while deliberately avoiding residues that may lead to developability liabilities.

Some minimalist library designs have successfully employed a single framework with diversity limited primarily to CDR-H3, demonstrating that framework diversity is not always essential for successful antibody discovery <Paper corpusId="270629223" paperTitle="(Hutchings et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. However, these approaches typically require careful selection of the framework and strategic diversity introduction to compensate for the limited structural variation.

The evolution of framework selection and optimization reflects the industry's growing understanding that successful antibody discovery requires not just high-affinity binders but molecules with favorable developability characteristics suitable for therapeutic applications <Paper corpusId="10576257" paperTitle="(Ponsel et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>.

paper.title: Monoclonal Antibody Development for Cancer Treatment Using the Phage Display Library Platform

snippets: The journey of generating antibodies through phage display technology commences with the construction of a diverse library. This process entails integrating genetic material encoding antibody fragments, such as antibodies' heavy and light chains, single-chain variable fragments (scFvs), Fabs, or peptides, into the genome of bacteriophages, notably filamentous ones like M13 (Jones et al., 2016). This fusion results in the expression of a multitude of unique antibody candidates on the surface of phages, forming the basis of the library. The diversity of this library, ranging from millions to billions of variants, lays the groundwork for the subsequent exploration of potential binding partners (Figure 1) (Parmley et al., 1988)

Constructing a phage display library involves several key steps aimed at generating a diverse repertoire of displayed peptides or proteins for subsequent screening against target molecules. Initially, a source of genetic material encoding the desired peptides or proteins is obtained, which can include synthetic DNA sequences, cDNA libraries, or genomic DNA. Next, this genetic material is ligated into a phagemid vector, which contains the genetic elements necessary for phage display, including a phage coat protein gene fused to the peptide or protein of interest. The ligated DNA is then introduced into competent Escherichia coli cells via transformation, where it undergoes replication and amplification. Following transformation, the bacterial cells are infected with helper phage, which provides the necessary components for packaging the phagemid DNA into phage particles. The infected cells are then cultured to allow for phage production, and the resulting phage display library is harvested by collecting the culture supernatant or lysing the bacterial cells to release the phage particles. The library can be further characterized by sequencing a subset of clones to assess diversity and by performing binding assays to confirm the display of the desired peptides or proteins (Figure 2) [12].

snippets: Antibody-based proteomics offers distinct advantages in the analysis of complex samples for discovery and validation of biomarkers associated with disease. snippets: In general, combinatorial antibody libraries are constructed from mRNA or 2 of 11 RNA extracted from B cells of immunized or naïve donors. paper.title: A White Plaque, Associated with Genomic Deletion, Derived from M13KE-Based Peptide Library Is Enriched in a Target-Unrelated Manner during Phage Display Biopanning Due to Propagation Advantage

snippets: The nonspecific enrichment of target-unrelated peptides during biopanning remains a major drawback for phage display technology. The commercial Ph.D.TM-7 phage display library is used extensively for peptide discovery. This library is based on the M13KE vector, which carries the lacZα sequence, leading to the formation of blue plaques on IPTG-X-gal agar plates. In the current study, we report the isolation of a fast-propagating white clone (displaying WSLGYTG peptide) identified through screening against a recombinant protein. Sanger sequencing demonstrated that white plaques are not contamination from environmental M13-like phages, but derive from the library itself. Whole genome sequencing revealed that the white color of the plaques results from a large 827-nucleotide genomic deletion. The phenotypic characterization of propagation capacity through plaque count- and NGS-based competitive propagation assay supported the higher propagation rate of Ph-WSLGYTG clone compared with the library. According to our data, white plaques are likely to arise endogenously in Ph.D. libraries due to mutations in the M13KE genome and should not always be viewed as exogenous contamination. Our findings also led to the conclusion that the deletion observed here might be an ancestral mutation already present in the naïve library, which causes target-unrelated nonspecific enrichment of white clone during biopanning due to propagation advantage.

sections.title: Factors Affecting Selection and Screening
sections.tldr: The success of phage display antibody discovery is influenced by multiple factors during selection and screening phases, including binding conditions, amplification bias, target complexity, and screening methodology. Addressing these challenges through optimized selection strategies and advanced screening technologies is critical for isolating antibodies with both desired binding properties and favorable developability characteristics. sections.text:
The effectiveness of phage display antibody discovery is significantly impacted by factors that influence both the selection (binding) and amplification phases of the biopanning process. Ideally, selection would be dominated by binding affinity, with all retrieved clones amplifying equally during propagation. However, in reality, amplification efficiency varies widely among different antibody sequences, and after multiple rounds of panning, the output repertoire often includes rapidly amplified sequences with low or no binding activity, significantly diminishing discovery efficiency <Paper corpusId="249328057" paperTitle="(Bai et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

This amplification bias represents a major challenge in phage display, as fast-propagating clones can become overrepresented during library amplification, leading to target-unrelated enrichment <Paper corpusId="259311093" paperTitle="(Palma, 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="247606549" paperTitle="(Sell et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. To mitigate this issue, it is recommended to use the original phage from the library generation rather than reamplified phage for repeated selection campaigns, as reamplification biases the library toward clones with higher expression rates <Paper corpusId="273373241" paperTitle="(Peng et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

Target complexity presents another significant challenge, particularly when using whole cells for phenotypic discovery. In these cases, the output phage pool typically contains thousands of antibodies binding potentially hundreds of different cell surface receptors. Clonal expansion throughout the enrichment process results in extremely complex output pools where a few antibodies are highly abundant while the majority are very rare. This creates a substantial challenge during screening, as only a fraction of antibodies can be tested using conventional binding analysis, typically identifying only the most abundant clones binding to one or a few targets <Paper corpusId="198963158" paperTitle="(Ljungars et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

The evolution of selection and screening strategies reflects a significant shift in priorities. While early phage display campaigns focused primarily on selecting antibodies with high specificity and affinity, the field has recognized that additional properties significantly impact therapeutic success. These "developability" properties include cross-reactivity against human targets and orthologs from relevant toxicology species, solubility, expression yield, and thermal and long-term stability <Paper corpusId="202024685" paperTitle="(Almagro et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

Advanced screening methods have been developed to address these challenges. Deep sequencing of unselected and selected phage libraries using next-generation sequencing platforms allows for in-depth evaluation of enrichment landscapes in CDR sequences and amino acid substitutions <Paper corpusId="3155125" paperTitle="(Hu et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach enables more efficient identification of beneficial mutations during affinity maturation campaigns and helps overcome the limitations of traditional screening methods.

The complexity of screening is further influenced by library design factors such as the length and nature (linear versus cyclic) of displayed peptides, which significantly impact selection outcomes. Shorter peptides offer increased flexibility but may have lower affinities and more nonspecific interactions, while longer peptides provide more interaction potential but may face structural constraints <Paper corpusId="259311093" paperTitle="(Palma, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

Despite these challenges, continuing innovations are improving phage display selection and screening. These include creating more diverse phage libraries, optimizing selection methods, and integrating advanced screening techniques to target complex biological environments <Paper corpusId="272630189" paperTitle="(Cui et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="214187873" paperTitle="(Simonetti et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="252893100" paperTitle="(Miki et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="259844290" paperTitle="(Guerlavais et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. Pattern enrichment analysis, for instance, allows comparison of selected versus unselected sequence datasets with high coverage, facilitating identification of key binding residues <Paper corpusId="252893100" paperTitle="(Miki et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

Specialized approaches have also been developed for particular applications, such as membrane protein targeting. These involve selecting "specialized" libraries containing phage-displayed antibodies that bind to membrane proteins, followed by efficient differential screening using minimal amounts of biological samples <Paper corpusId="8071794" paperTitle="(Monaci et al., 2008)" isShortName></Paper>. Such targeted approaches help overcome the inherent challenges of selecting against complex targets in competitive environments.

paper.title: Pattern enrichment analysis for phage selection of stapled peptide ligands

snippets: Phage display is the most widely used technique to discover de novo peptides that bind to target proteins. However, it is associated with some challenges such as compositional bias. In this study, to overcome these difficulties, we devised a ‘pattern enrichment analysis.’ In this method, two samples (one obtained by affinity selection, the other simply amplified without selection) are prepared, and the two sequence datasets read on next-generation sequencer are compared to find the three-residue pattern most enriched in the selected sample. This allows us to compare two sequence datasets with high coverage and facilitates the identification of peptide sequences and the key residues for binding. We also demonstrated that this approach in the combination with structured peptide libraries allowed spatial mapping of the enriched sequence patterns. Here, we prepared a phage library displaying chemically stapled helical peptides with the X1C2X3X4X5X6X7X8C9X10 sequence, where X is any amino acid. To validate our method, we performed screening against the HDM2 protein. The results showed that the hydrophobic residues (Phe, Tyr, Trp and Leu) that are key to interactions with HDM2 were clearly identified by the pattern enrichment analysis. We also performed selection targeting the SARS-CoV-2 spike RBD in the same manner. The results showed that similar patterns were enriched among the hit peptides that inhibited the protein–protein interaction.

Intracellular proteolysis of ALRN-6924 forms a long-acting active metabolite with potent MDM2 and MDMX binding affinity and slow dissociation kinetics. At high doses, ALRN-6924 exhibits on-mechanism anticancer activity in TP53-WT tumor models. At lower doses, ALRN-6924 transiently arrests the cell cycle in healthy tissues to protect them from chemotherapy without protecting the TP53-mutant cancer cells. These results support the continued clinical evaluation of ALRN-6924 as an anticancer and chemoprotection agent.

The amino acid sequence of VH3-CDR3, the hypervariable region which in most cases acts as a major binding determinant [6][7][8], is a unique and distinctive feature of each member of the repository. The Membranome phage-Ab collection hosts VH-CDR3 sequences ranging from 3 to 25 residues, with the frequency peaking around 10 residues, and analysis of the complete scFv region reveals a broad set of germline families. Together these two findings indicate that a wide variety of binding motifs are present in the collection.
